title: Copernican Revolution üåç
ques: Why was the **heliocentric model** such a revolutionary change?

answer.content:
**Copernican Revolution (1543):**

**Before:** Earth at center (Ptolemy)
**After:** Sun at center (Copernicus)

**Why Revolutionary:**
- Earth became just another planet
- Humans not at center of universe
- Mathematical simplicity
- Challenged Church authority

**Timeline:**
| Year | Scientist | Contribution |
|------|-----------|-------------|
| 1543 | Copernicus | Heliocentric theory |
| 1609 | Kepler | Elliptical orbits |
| 1610 | Galileo | Telescope evidence |
| 1687 | Newton | Gravitational explanation |

explanation: Copernicus published on his deathbed to avoid controversy. Book banned by Church until 1758.

title: Moon Landing üåô
ques: What made **Apollo 11** a milestone for humanity?

answer.content:
**Apollo 11 (July 20, 1969):**

**Crew:**
- Neil Armstrong (first to walk)
- Buzz Aldrin (second)
- Michael Collins (orbited Moon)

**Famous Words:**
"That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind"

**Achievements:**
| Aspect | Significance |
|--------|-------------|
| Technical | 400,000 people working together |
| Political | Won Space Race |
| Scientific | Lunar samples returned |
| Cultural | Inspired generations |

explanation: Computer on Apollo had less power than a calculator today. Achievement was primarily engineering.

title: Human Genome Project üß¨
ques: What was the **Human Genome Project** and its impact?

answer.content:
**Human Genome Project (1990-2003):**

**Goals:**
- Sequence all ~3 billion base pairs
- Identify all ~20,000 genes
- Cost: $3 billion

**Impact:**
| Field | Application |
|-------|------------|
| Medicine | Personalized medicine |
| Forensics | DNA fingerprinting |
| Evolution | Comparative genomics |
| Agriculture | Crop improvement |

**Today:**
Sequencing costs dropped from $3B to ~$600

explanation: Race between public (HGP) and private (Celera) made headlines. Both declared completion together.

title: Atomic Bomb ‚ò¢Ô∏è
ques: What was the **Manhattan Project** and its scientific legacy?

answer.content:
**Manhattan Project (1942-1945):**

**Scientists:**
- Oppenheimer (director)
- Fermi, Bohr, Feynman, and many others

**Achievements:**
- First nuclear reactor (1942)
- Trinity test (July 16, 1945)
- Hiroshima and Nagasaki (August 1945)

**Scientific Legacy:**
| Positive | Negative |
|----------|----------|
| Nuclear energy | Arms race |
| Big Science model | Environmental damage |
| Accelerators | Proliferation concerns |

explanation: Oppenheimer quoted Bhagavad Gita: "Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds." Many scientists deeply conflicted.

title: Germ Theory Acceptance ü¶†
ques: When did **germ theory** replace miasma theory?

answer.content:
**Paradigm Shift (1860s-1880s):**

**Old Theory (Miasma):**
- Disease from "bad air"
- Swamps, rotting matter
- Explained malaria ("bad air")

**New Theory (Germs):**
- Specific microorganisms cause specific diseases
- Koch's postulates proved causation
- Led to antiseptics, hygiene

**Key Events:**
| Year | Event |
|------|-------|
| 1847 | Semmelweis: Handwashing |
| 1865 | Lister: Antiseptic surgery |
| 1876 | Koch: Anthrax bacillus |

explanation: Semmelweis was ridiculed and died in asylum. His ideas accepted only after Pasteur and Koch.

title: Vaccination Milestones üíâ
ques: Trace the **history of vaccination** from Jenner to COVID-19.

answer.content:
**Vaccination Timeline:**

| Year | Vaccine | Scientist |
|------|---------|----------|
| 1796 | Smallpox | Jenner |
| 1885 | Rabies | Pasteur |
| 1955 | Polio (injected) | Salk |
| 1962 | Polio (oral) | Sabin |
| 1963 | Measles | Enders |
| 2020 | COVID-19 mRNA | Moderna, Pfizer |

**Smallpox:** Only human disease eradicated (1980)
**mRNA:** New platform, developed in record time

explanation: Vaccines have saved more lives than any other medical intervention. Anti-vaccine movements are not new.

title: Internet Creation üåê
ques: How did the **Internet** evolve from ARPANET?

answer.content:
**Internet Timeline:**

| Year | Milestone |
|------|----------|
| 1969 | ARPANET (4 nodes) |
| 1971 | First email |
| 1983 | TCP/IP adopted |
| 1989 | World Wide Web (Berners-Lee) |
| 1991 | WWW public |
| 1993 | Mosaic browser |

**Key Innovations:**
- Packet switching
- Decentralized design (survive attack)
- Open protocols
- Hypertext (links)

explanation: Originally military project, now connects billions. Web is an application on top of internet.

title: Theory of Relativity üìê
ques: What was the **1919 eclipse expedition** that confirmed Einstein?

answer.content:
**Eddington Eclipse Expedition:**

**The Prediction:**
Light from stars would bend around Sun

**The Test (May 29, 1919):**
- Two expeditions (Africa, Brazil)
- Photographed stars near Sun during eclipse
- Positions shifted by predicted amount

**Headlines:**
"LIGHTS ALL ASKEW IN THE HEAVENS"

**Impact:**
- Einstein became world famous overnight
- General relativity accepted
- Science as front-page news

explanation: Actually marginal confirmation; later tests more precise. But cultural impact was enormous.

title: First Flight ‚úàÔ∏è
ques: How did the **Wright Brothers** achieve powered flight?

answer.content:
**Kitty Hawk (December 17, 1903):**

**Flight Stats:**
- Distance: 120 feet (first), 852 feet (fourth)
- Duration: 12 seconds (first), 59 seconds (fourth)
- Height: ~10 feet

**Why They Succeeded:**
| Factor | Approach |
|--------|----------|
| Wing design | Wind tunnel testing |
| Control | Three-axis control |
| Engine | Lightweight, built their own |
| Systematic | Scientific method |

explanation: Others were ahead on engines and structures; Wrights solved control problem. Bicycle business funded research.

title: Plate Tectonics üåç
ques: How was **plate tectonics** finally accepted in the 1960s?

answer.content:
**Plate Tectonics Revolution:**

**Wegener's Hypothesis (1912):**
Continents drift - but no mechanism

**Key Evidence (1950s-60s):**
| Evidence | Discoverer |
|----------|------------|
| Seafloor spreading | Hess, Dietz |
| Magnetic reversals | Vine, Matthews |
| Ocean floor mapping | Tharp, Heezen |

**Acceptance:**
- 1960s: Plate tectonics synthesized
- Explains earthquakes, volcanoes, mountains
- Unifies geology

explanation: Wegener died (1930) thinking he was wrong. Vindicated 30 years later. Marie Tharp's maps were crucial.
